m:properties.d:title: Developing Games for Windows Phone 7 with XNA 4.0
m:properties.d:description: Chris G. Williams will be presenting Developing Games for Windows Phone 7 with XNA 4.0'. In this talk, he'll cover what's new in XNA 4.0, especially as it pertains to Windows Phone 7. He'll cover phone features, using the emulator and how to take advantage of the various sensors (like the Accelerometer) and features (MultiTouch, Gestures, Push Notifications, etc) in your games.

m:properties.d:title: Wait" I am not Dead Yet, Just Tombstoned
m:properties.d:description: Managing state and navigating through windows phone applications is a little different from a normal web or desktop application. In this seminar you will learn the various ways to navigate through your application and what to do when your application is tombstoned. You will learn various techniques for restoring state including using the built-in state bag and isolated storage. You will Learn The various methods of navigation in your phone app Methods of Storing and Retrieving State Detecting when an application is tombstoned versus when it is closed

m:properties.d:title: Data Binding in Expression Blend
m:properties.d:description: Data Binding is one of the key features of WPF and Silverlight. This presentation demonstrates and explains the Data Binding tools and features of Blend. Includes discussions of Data Context, Value Converters, Element Binding, Sample Data and more.& With these tools you really can bind anything to anything.

m:properties.d:title: Expression Blend and the Visual State Manager: A Deep Dive
m:properties.d:description: The Visual State Manager (VSM) is a must have tool in your Silverlight and WPF arsenal. In this session, we will take a deep dive into using the VSM in Expression Blend. Topics will include using the VSM for Templating, creating custom States, using the GoToState Behavior, and applying Transitions and Effects.

m:properties.d:title: Architecting a Business Application for Windows Phone
m:properties.d:description: Developing a business application to run in WPF or on a website is very different from a mobile device. Creating an efficient architecture can also be very different for a Windows Phone. In this seminar you will learn tips on how to create a re-useable architecture. In addition you will see how to present data to your business users in such a way that is easy to understand and navigate through. A real-world, business application will be shown and you will learn how the application was created. You will Learn Architecting a Windows Phone Application Framework considerations for Re-using class libraries in WPF, Silverlight and Windows Phone Retrieving data and exposing data through WCF effectively UI tips for business applications on a Mobile Device

m:properties.d:title: 10 Cool Ways to use the Silverlight ListBox
m:properties.d:description: The ListBox control in Silverlight is very powerful. In this seminar you will see all the various things you can do to present some great user interfaces with this control. You can present multiple columns, multiple lines per row, make the list box horizontal, even perform sorting and grouping. All of this and more is available with this powerful control. You will Learn Multiple Columns and Multiple Lines per Item\ Horizontal List Boxes Using Templates Sorting, Grouping and Filtering Data Using Value Converters

m:properties.d:title: Introduction to iPhone Development for .NET/C# Developers with MonoTouch
m:properties.d:description: Introduction to iPhone/iPad for .NET/C# developers using MonoTouch Session Type: 1 hour session Description: This session will introduce writing native applications geared for the iOS Platform based on .NET/C#/Mono. We'll examine the overall architecture of MonoTouch, discuss how it integrates with the iPhone, debug with MonoTouch, and look at a couple of example apps written with MonoTouch. Who this session is for: This session is for the .NET developer who wants to move to the iOS Mobile Platform. While the session will be introductory for the iOS Platform, it will be intermediate/expert for those on the .NET Platform. Problem statement: iOS development predominantly uses the ObjectiveC language and uses the XCode IDE. If a developer or company has already made an investment in .NET, the time to learn ObjectiveC and XCode along with the Android Mobile Platform is significant. An attendee of this session will be able to take their existing knowledge of .NET/C# and immediately apply it to writing apps for the iOS Mobile Platform. The importance of this should not be understated. Learning a new language results in a significant learning curve and requires a large investment of time. Add in the time required to learn XCode, and that amount increases even more. With this session, you will learn how to develop iOS applications using MonoDevelop and MonoTouch. What attendees will take away: Attendees will be able to immediately begin development on iOS in MonoTouch using their existing language skills. The benefit of attending this session: Attendees will be able to begin development on iOS without the learning curve of a new language and a new development environment. The benefit is that .NET developers will be effective using MonoTouch at a lower time investment than switching development languages.

m:properties.d:title: Introduction to Android Development for .NET/C# Developers using MonoDroid
m:properties.d:description: Android for .NET/C# Developers using MonoDroid Session Type: Android Developer Essentials Session length: 1 hour Description: This session will introduce writing native applications geared for the Android Platform based on .NET/C#/Mono. We'll examine the overall architecture of MonoDroid, discuss how it integrates with Visual Studio, debug with MonoDroid, and look at a couple of example apps written with MonoDroid. Who is this session for: This session is for the .NET developer that wants to move to the Android Mobile Platform. While the session will be introductory for the Android Platform, it will be intermediate/expert for those on the .NET Platform. Problem statement: Android development is predominantly with the Java Language based on the Java VM "Dalvik" using the Eclipse IDE. If a developer or company has already made a significant investment in .NET, the time to learn Java and the Android Mobile Platform is significant. An attendee of this session will be able to take their existing knowledge of .NET/C# and Visual studio and immediately apply this to writing apps for the Android Mobile Platform. The significance of this should not be understated. Learning a new language, no matter how similar to .NET/C#, results in a significant learning curve as well as a significant time investment. Add in the time required to learn Eclipse, and there is even more time required. With this session, you will learn how to develop Android Applications using Visual Studio and the Novell MonoDroid plugin. What will attendees take away: Attendees will be able to immediately begin development on Android in Visual Studio 2010 using their existing language skills and known development environment. The benefit to attending this session: Attendees will be able to begin development on Android without the learning curve of a new platform and a new development environment. The benefit is that .NET developers will be effective using MonoDroid at a lower time investment than switching development platforms.

m:properties.d:title: SharePoint for ASP.NET Developers
m:properties.d:description: SharePoint is one of Microsoft's most successful products ever. As adoption grows, it becomes more and more likely that you, the ASP.NET developer, will be asked to start building customizations for SharePoint. Visual Studio 2010 includes extensive tooling that will aid you, but you'll need to become familiar with some fundamental concepts before diving into code. This session is designed to introduce you to these concepts, laying the foundation needed before moving to File | New Project.

m:properties.d:title: What's New in SharePoint 2010 for Developers
m:properties.d:description: SharePoint 2010 has a plethora new developer oriented features. There is extensive new tooling in Visual Studio 2010, there is the ability to develop on client operating systems, there is an entirely new APIs for building remote applications, there are new mechanisms to access list data in a strongly-typed manner, and so much more. This whirlwind tour around SharePoint 2010 will demonstrate as many of these new features as possible in the time allotted.

m:properties.d:title: SharePoint & jQuery - What's the real story?
m:properties.d:description: jQuery is the current "SharePoint Silver Bullet" promising to cure all your SharePoint ailments allowing customizations that at one point were unattainable without cracking open Visual Studio. But what is the real story with jQuery and SharePoint? How do you implement it with SharePoint? Should you implement it? Is it all a big hoax or is jQuery the missing piece to your SharePoint development took kit? In this session attendees will learn: 1) Best practices for deploying jQuery in a maintainable way in their organizations 2) What can be done quickly and powerfully in jQuery taking advantage of incredible third party libraries 3) What are the real consequences of using jQuery and when should you NOT use it.

m:properties.d:title: Multithreaded Web Applications
m:properties.d:description: As our web application get more complex, there are times when parallel processing can greatly increase the performance of our applications. This talk will take a look at the challenges of using multithreaded programming in the web environment. Discover the scenarios in which your web application can safely and successfully benefit from parallel processing.

m:properties.d:title: Beginning Xbox 360 development with the XNA Framework
m:properties.d:description: While many of us dream of jobs in game development, XNA Game Studio and Microsoft's AppHub give you the tools necessary to make and publish your own games for the Xbox Live Indie Games Marketplace. Attendees will given a brief overview of using XNA Game Studio to create software for the Xbox 360.

m:properties.d:title: Xbox 360 Indie Game Design Using XNA
m:properties.d:description: The methods for producing quality games that perform in real time are much different than the methods used to produce quality productivity software. This session will present attendees with the nuances of proper game design by introducing topics such as the game loop, collision detection, and processing inputs from analog devices.

m:properties.d:title: Getting Started With F# Web Development
m:properties.d:description: Many of the features provided by F# lend themselves well to web development. In this talk, we will quickly go over some of the basics of the F# language, then dive into four quick ways to get started developing web application in F#. By the end, we will have built an F# and C# Silverlight application, an F# only Silverlight application, an F# and C# ASP.NET MVC 2 web application, and a web application with a platform called WebSharper.

m:properties.d:title: jQuery 101
m:properties.d:description: Web 2.0 is here to stay. jQuery is a JavaScript library that abstracts away all of the gory details of working with JavaScript for web applicatons. This session will demonstrate how to added Jquery to your ASP.NET applications today. This session will focus on proper uses of Jquery including how to organize your javascript code, how to use selectors in Jquery. How to manipulate your web content dynamically. Along with uses of the standard Jquery library time will also be spent exploring some of the most useful Jquery plugs ins.

m:properties.d:title: Creating Custom Actions in SharePoint (Part 1 - SharePoint 2007)
m:properties.d:description: Custom Actions control features in SharePoint such as the Edit Control Block, the Site Actions menu, toolbars, and the links within the Site Settings page. Learn how to leverage Custom Actions to extend the SharePoint User Interface. This session will describe the basics of Custom Actions, a demonstration to build one or more and apply them to a site in SharePoint, as well as provide resources for additional information.

m:properties.d:title: Creating Custom Actions in SharePoint (Part 2 - 2010)
m:properties.d:description: Custom Actions control features in SharePoint such as the List Item Menu, the Site Actions menu, toolbars, and the links within the Site Settings page, as well as the Ribbon UI in SharePoint 2010. Learn how to leverage Custom Actions to extend the SharePoint User Interface. This session will describe the basics of Custom Actions, demonstrations to build and apply them in SharePoint, as well as provide resources for additional information.

m:properties.d:title: Introduction to Ruby on Rails
m:properties.d:description: One of the premier web development platforms is Ruby on Rails. In this session you will learn: basic understanding of how rails applications are structured and work, how to build a a rails application, how to add validations, how to use layouts and partials to your advantage and finally how to deploy your application to the cloud using Heroku. If you have never used Rails and are curious this session is for you.

m:properties.d:title: Getting started with Ruby on Rails
m:properties.d:description: Michael provides a basic introduction to Ruby on Rails, the very popular web framework. We will work through getting a basic site up and running, covering MVC, routes, ActiveRecord, and testing a rails app. This is a hands-on session. Bring your laptop with Ruby 1.9.2 and Rails 3 already installed.

m:properties.d:title: MacRuby and HotCocoa
m:properties.d:description: MacRuby is an implementation of Ruby 1.9 directly on top of Mac OS X core technologies. HotCocoa is a thin, idiomatic Ruby layer that sits above Cocoa and other frameworks. Together, they make building Mac applications pain free (for Rubyists). Doc shows us how to get started and then walks us through the creation of a simple app.

m:properties.d:title: The Technical Debt Trap
m:properties.d:description: Technical Debt has become a catch-all phrase for any code that needs to be re-worked. Much like Refactoring has become a catch-all phrase for any activity that involves changing code. These fundamental misunderstandings and comfortable yet mis-applied metaphors have resulted in a plethora of poor decisions. What is technical debt? What is not technical debt? Why should we care? What is the cost of misunderstanding? What do we do about it? Doc discusses the origins of the metaphor, what it means today, and how we properly identify and manage technical debt.

m:properties.d:title: Orchard - an Introduction to an Open Source Content Management System
m:properties.d:description: The Orchard Project (orchardproject.net) is an open source content management system built on the ASP MVC 3.0 framework. In this session, John will cover the basics of what Orchard is and how you can use this powerful tool to quickly stand up content-driven websites.

m:properties.d:title: How to say "YES" to everything, but on your own terms
m:properties.d:description: As a project manager, we find ourselves responsible for many things but not necessarily authorized to fully manage or control those events. Often times our resources are shared across project, managers, and locations. Often times our timetables and schedules overlap. Often times new requests come in daily. We feel uncomfortable saying "no" to these requests because We feel it's our job We feel saying NO is a fast track out of our job. But the main reason saying "NO" feels wrong is that it a defeatists' attitude. We're telling people: there isn't enough time, there isn't enough resources, there isn't enough me. We're telling people "we can't". This presentation covers 7 key strategies for saying "YES to everything" but on your own terms. The key to saying "YES" is understanding the underlining essence of the goal and finding alternative ways in accomplishing the purpose (versus just the task). This is a great presentation for project managers and life in general. These principles translates to project managers, developers, career development, and work life balance strategies. This is an uplifting and transformational seminar.

m:properties.d:title: 7 Habits of Highly Effective Project Managers
m:properties.d:description: As a project manager, we find ourselves responsible for many things but not necessarily authorized to fully manage or control those events. In this presentation, I take Steven Covey's 7 Habits and translate them into a project management environment. This presentation details how the 7 Habits can be used directly into the project management arena to gather consensus, accountability and loyalty within your work team. Using the 7 Habits in the way this presentation conveys create a high-performing and inspired project team. Audience will not only gain the essence of the 7 Habits, but also how to use them to make an impact in their project management role.

m:properties.d:title: The Decoder Ring for Data Warehousing / Business Intelligence with SQL Server
m:properties.d:description: Business Intelligence is growing at an astounding rate. DBAs and Database Developers are being asked to implement databases with non-traditional design, and are having a lot of new vocabulary thrown their way. In this concepts talk you will learn the ideas behind building and designing data warehouses, and cut through some of the arcane terms so you will walk away with a clear understanding of what words like dimensions, facts, and measures mean. You'll also be given a brief overview of the tools Microsoft makes available for implementing a DW/BI solution.

m:properties.d:title: Searching Unstructured Text Data - SQL Server Full Text Searching for DBAs and Developers
m:properties.d:description: Users have become accustomed to the simple interfaces of search engines such as Microsoft BING and Google. They want to be able to enter key words and have their applications sift through vast quantities of text to get results quickly. Did you know that you can give your users that search ability? SQL Server Full Text Searching is the key. And it's as easy as 1-2-3" Come and learn the how to setup and use full text searching with SQL Server. Chock full of demonstrations this session will start with setting up full text searching on the database and end with issuing a full text query from within a WPF .Net application.

m:properties.d:title: Overview of the Microsoft SQL Server Business Intelligence Toolset
m:properties.d:description: In this session, attendees will get an overview of the specific tools Microsoft offers to implement a Data Warehousing / Business Intelligence solution. To implement any DW/BI solution there are four basic tasks to perform: construct a data warehouse; load the warehouse through an ETL tool; create analytics from the warehouse; and finally report. At the end of this session attendees will understand which Microsoft applications fill the needs for each of these tasks through the use of a real world demo. Starting with the Adventure Works Lite database, attendees will see how to use a Visual Studio 2010 Database Project to construct the data warehouse, then use SQL Server Integraion Services to populate it. A SQL Server Analysis Services project will then be used to create the analytical piece of the solution. SQL Server Reporting Services will then be used to generate a report that solves the real world business issue.

m:properties.d:title: Gaining the Competitive Edge: Build Your Best Resume
m:properties.d:description: Session Objectives To learn how to develop a resume to successfully manage different interview situations, participants will: Create a detailed list of personal strengths and identify key transferable skills Evaluate a resume like a manager to identify opportunities for improvement Integrate details into your resume to separate it from the competition Learn the 6 key questions to determine if your resume is right for the job

m:properties.d:title: Gaining the Competitive Edge: Impactful Interview Skills
m:properties.d:description: Session Objectives At the end of the session, participants will have learned skills to successfully manage different interview situations including: Ideas for differentiating your skills from the other candidates on phone and face-to-face interviews Learn how to master the top 5 "dos" and avoid the top 5 "don'ts" for live interviews as a candidate Develop answers to common interview questions through behavior-based examples Techniques to maintain focus during the interview for thorough answers and how to end the interview on a positive note Identify the ways candidates can keep an interviewer's attention and interest throughout the interview

m:properties.d:title: Inside the SQL Server Transaction Log
m:properties.d:description: To many DBAs, the transaction log is a black box that just works and doesn't need any attention. While this might be true on low activity SQL Server instances, for busy systems, the transaction log needs lots of focused attention if you want it to perform optimally and help provide higher availability. In this session, you learn how the transaction log works from the inside out, and how to optimize it for the best performance in most any environment. This session is targeted towards more experienced DBAs who are interested in the internal workings of the transaction log, and how to apply that knowledge to the real world.

m:properties.d:title: Beginning iOS Development, Part II
m:properties.d:description: In this session we will explore MVC in iOS with examples of several of the most common types of views and view controllers with a deeper dive into table view controllers and custom cells. Throughout, we will enforce lessons on memory management and the object lifecycle.

m:properties.d:title: Beginning iOS Development, Part III
m:properties.d:description: In this session we will explore Objective-C topics like Protocols, Categories, and Blocks. We also will take a look at network communication and practical uses of web services and JSON. We will also introduce Core Data. Finally, we will throw in a little eye candy with Core Animation.

m:properties.d:title: The Rich Standard: Getting Familiar with HTML 5
m:properties.d:description: HTML 5 may take some time to find full support in all major browsers, but you may be surprised to discover how many of HTML 5's features are available today" HTML 5 is the next generation standard for web applications, and it promises to give plug-in based RIAs a serious challenge. In this demo heavy session, you'll see HTML 5 in action and learn what you can do with today's browser support for the new standard. If you're building rich web applications and you've never touched HTML 5, this session is a must see.

m:properties.d:title: Doing More with LESS for CSS
m:properties.d:description: As CSS3 adds support for rich styling in standards-based web applications, style sheet markup can quickly get out of control" Many CSS effects today require repetitive rules to cover the proprietary browser CSS prefixes. LESS for CSS is an open source framework that makes modern CSS more manageable. With support for variables, mix-ins, nested CSS rules, and operations, LESS finally makes complex CSS easy to maintain. In this session, you will discover how LESS can be easily adopted in any ASP.NET project and learn about tools that make it easy to work with LESS in Visual Studio 2010.

m:properties.d:title: HTML5 and CSS3 Techniques You Can Use Today
m:properties.d:description: As more browsers deliver rich support for the next generation of standards-based web development, new techniques are enabling web developers to design with unprecedented levels of control. In this session, you will learn practical HTML5 and CSS3 techniques that you can use in any web project today. Learn how to easily add drop shadows to HTML objects, how to quickly create rounded corners, how to use custom fonts, and even how to animate with CSS. All techniques will be demonstrated with special attention to cross-browser support and tips for supporting older browsers.

m:properties.d:title: Building RESTful Applications with the Open Data Protocol
m:properties.d:description: Applications today are expected to expose their data and consume data-centric services via REST. In this session we discuss what REST is and have an overview of WCF Data Services and see how we can REST enable your data using the Open Data Protocol (OData). Then you will learn how to leverage existing skills related to Visual Studio, LINQ and data access to customize the behavior, control-flow, security model and experience of your data service. We will then see how to enable data-binding to traditional ASP.NET controls as well as Silverlight and Excel PowerPivot. We'll then turn to consuming SharePoint and other OData based applications in .NET as well as from a non-Microsoft client. This is a very demo intensive session.

m:properties.d:title: db4o - the quick and easy object database
m:properties.d:description: Sometimes a relational database is not a good fit for your application. If you need raw speed, work with complex entities, or are writing embedded software, then db4o (for .NET or Java) might be the persistence solution you need. db4o gives you a quick and easy way to get data persistence going without configuring servers, ORMs, or maintaining tables and stored procedures. This session will give a code-focused introduction to db4o, identify some good use cases for db4o, and give you a small taste of the more advanced topics to whet your appetite.

m:properties.d:title: Writing great PHP: with Cake, you can
m:properties.d:description: PHP gets a bad rap among software craftsmen because so many legacy PHP apps are poorly written and poorly maintained. What if there was a way to emphasize the positives of PHP (quick ramp-up, popularity, ubiquity) while restraining the negatives? With CakePHP, a popular MVC framework for PHP, now you can" Write apps with separation of concerns, testability, and SOLID principles in mind. In this session, you will learn to write a very simple introductory CakePHP app and learn how to test it.

m:properties.d:title: SOLID Development Patterns for Mere Mortals
m:properties.d:description: Software development patterns have been around long before the MVC Framework gained momentum. In this session we will start with a review of Robert C. Martin's (Uncle Bob) SOLID macronym. After building the proper foundation, I will show you several development patterns, their C# implementation, and when and how they should be used in modern software development.

m:properties.d:title: Lessons Learned: Being Agile in the Waterfall Sandbox
m:properties.d:description: Scrum and XP have found a strong following in the development community. But most non-development groups (such as Web Administrators, Production Support, Security, Testing, and Users/Stake Holders) inside the enterprise are not only far from agile, that are not trying to move to be more agile. I start with a refresher on Scrum, and then use real experiences from large enterprise development projects to teach you how to effectively work with non-agile teams. Instead of trying to "convert" them, I discuss strategies to adapt to their needs while remaining agile in the development realm.

m:properties.d:title: Sun Tzu's Art of War translated for Project Management
m:properties.d:description: Sun Tsu was a practical philosopher who wrote the The Art of War approximately 500 B.C. For centuries The Art of War was held the preeminent position among both Chinese and Japanese strategist. In 2001 Gerald Michaelson translated these strategies for the business world, titled, The Art of War for Managers. Borrowing against both Sun Tsu and Gerald Michaelson's ideas, we've translated for highly successful project managers.

m:properties.d:title: The Sterling Database for Silverlight and Windows Phone 7
m:properties.d:description: The release of Silverlight 4 and Windows Phone 7 have created an explosion of line of business applications written in Silverlight. The framework provides a powerful advantage with its ability to run offline and disconnected from the network. For browser applications this provides a unique data storage challenge. Windows Phone 7 applications must also cater to the "tombstoning" scenario and efficiently serialize and rehydrate data when the program is swapped to the background and back. Sterling is an open source object-oriented database that addresses these needs by storing data in isolated storage. Sterling works with existing classes/types and is extremely lightweight. Learn how to use Sterling from its creator, Jeremy Likness, when he walks you through various scenarios and features involving indexes, LINQ to object queries, foreign keys, triggers, encryption, and compression.

m:properties.d:title: Silverlight 5 for Line of Business Applications
m:properties.d:description: Silverlight 5 has been announced and will provide a variety of incredible features beneficial to line of business applications. Microsoft Silverlight MVP Jeremy Likness will cover these features and teach you how to produce high performance scalable applications using the latest Silverlight framework. Learn how Postscript printing, improved MVVM support with XAML and data-binding debugging, implicit data templates, style binding, WS-Trust support, 64-bit support and more enhance the current runtime and take Silverlight to the next level within the enterprise.

m:properties.d:title: Connecting Windows Phone 7 and Azure with WCF
m:properties.d:description: Windows Phone 7 and Azure are hot topics this year, and the two together is a winning combination. In this session, we'll have a short overview of Azure and WCF, then look at the free tools and guidelines used to build applications for WP7 (you don't even need a phone to get started). We'll then dig in and create a Windows Phone 7 application which utilizes data stored in Azure and accessed via WCF.

m:properties.d:title: Enterprise Performance Management using SQL Server 2008 R2 and SharePoint 2010
m:properties.d:description: Learn how to set up and manage an enterprise-scale performance management solution using the newest offerings from Microsoft. Establish a greater understanding of the components in SQL Server 2008 R2 and SharePoint 2010 that can enable your business to become a world competitor. Hear best practices on how to define, develop, and deploy key performance indicators, metrics, indicators, analytic charts, decomposition trees, and other useful tools to bring your EPM program to life.

m:properties.d:title: HTML5 vs. Silverlight
m:properties.d:description: You may have seen blog posts, tweets or heard people talking about how HTML5 is the browser plugin slayer. You might also have been confused by Microsoft's mixed signals about whether they are dropping Silverlight going forward to focus on HTML5. Whether its an industry leader's blog post or an interview with a corporate VP, everyone seems to have their own opinion ... and agenda. In this session, Matt makes an unbiased comparison between features of HTML5 and Silverlight today and going forward. You might be surprised by the result.

m:properties.d:title: Going Independent Workshop Part #1
m:properties.d:description: Breaking free from the confines of the cubicle farm and going out on your own can be one of the most satisfying things you do for your career. It can also be one of the most terrifying. Along with Mike, several consultants and other professionals will help answer the most common questions people ask such as: "How do I get started?", "Where do I find clients?", "How much do I charge?" and many others. Come find out if the grass really is greener on the other side. This session, when delivered as a workshop, is broken down into distinct deep-dives including "Finding Clients", "Setting Your Rate" and "Running a Business".

m:properties.d:title: Going Independent Workshop Part #2
m:properties.d:description: Breaking free from the confines of the cubicle farm and going out on your own can be one of the most satisfying things you do for your career. It can also be one of the most terrifying. Along with Mike, several consultants and other professionals will help answer the most common questions people ask such as: "How do I get started?", "Where do I find clients?", "How much do I charge?" and many others. Come find out if the grass really is greener on the other side. This session, when delivered as a workshop, is broken down into distinct deep-dives including "Finding Clients", "Setting Your Rate" and "Running a Business".

m:properties.d:title: Mocking Your Customer
m:properties.d:description: In the past I have found that customers like to change their mind about what they want. This normally happens once they see me implement what they originally asked for during the first round of requirements discussion. Developers work hard to put together the user interface using the designers, but it is not inexpensive to the customer base. Sure there are times when we hit the nail on the head, but normally I find the real solution does not shine until the customer "spits on it." Balsamiq Mockups is a designer that lets developers and non-developers alike to build wireframes/mockups. These are blueprints on how the application user interface can look or work. Developers and users can sit down and flow through the application before hours of development are completed. Balsamiq Mockups facilitates the creation of the wireframes with lots of controls that developers are use to in the toolboxes provided in the native application designers. Session take-aways: Understand the benefits of wireframing with your users Show how you can leverage customers and designers/artists to create mockups See how easy it is to create mockups Convince you that wireframing actually leads to more business, not take away revenues from development Demonstrate the different ways Balsamiq Mockups makes you a more effective developer/team

m:properties.d:title: The PowerShell Cookbook for SQL Server
m:properties.d:description: The best DBAs work hard so that they don't have to, well, work hard. In this session, we'll discuss how you can use the PowerShell cmdlets and snap-ins to create scripts that automate the more mundane tasks in your role as a DBA or developer. We'll create scripts that check the status of SQLAgent jobs, verify the configuration of your servers, and retrieves information from your SQL Server database. You can even store your results in a database table if you'd like. This session is mostly demos with only a few PowerPoint slides to get us started.

m:properties.d:title: iTextSharp and PDF Manipulation
m:properties.d:description: This class is an introduction to iTextSharp. iText is an open source java code that creates and manipulates PDF documents. iTextSharp is a dll wrapper around the iText Java code. This is an open source library and gives you the ability to manipulate PDF documents without having to purchase Adobe Acrobat. Although this has been around for a few years, very few developers know about this powerful library and how to use it. In this class we will show how you can create your own PDF documents. We will also show you how to fill in Acroforms programmatically without using Adobe Acrobat. We will also demonstrate how to annotate the document. This is a great tool for developers who need to serve out PDF documents on a web server. Since iText will not display or print a PDF documents, we will show you other free tools to print PDF's without the use of Adobe products.

m:properties.d:title: Windows Phone 7 Sound Generation in Silverlight
m:properties.d:description: In this class we will create a Silverlight app that has a simple sound generator creating sine waves and playing them on the phone. To accomplish this, we will use the DynamicSoundEffectsInstance in the XNA Framework. We will explore the basics of creating sound patterns and playing them. We will create an app that you will be able to select the frequency and volume to play in the phone. We will also explore creating 2 channel sound patterns (stereo). We will play one tone in the left speaker and one tone in the right. We also will demonstrate with different wave tones such as square waves which produce a different type of sound from the sine wave. We will also be putting a series of tone together and playing a simple melody. Afterwards you will have an understanding of how to add sound effects to your Silverlight app that you can create yourself.

m:properties.d:title: Amplify Your jQuery Code with Request, Store, and Pub/Sub
m:properties.d:description: jQuery has grown to become a very popular JavaScript library, but unless you are careful it can easily morph into a mess of tightly coupled logic spread throughout your web application. Amplify is a new library that provides a set of components designed to solve common web applications problems. It provides three major components: Request, Store, and Pub/Sub. Amplify Store handles persistent client-side storage for your application and provides fallback solutions for non-supported browsers, Amplify Request provides an abstraction layer on top of jQuery's ajax method to help hide the underlying data source, and Amplify Pub/Sub provides an easy way to implement the observer design pattern into your application. During this talk we will walk through an application showing how these new components can help you loosely couple your code and we will address some nice ways to organize your code as well.

m:properties.d:title: The Kinect API
m:properties.d:description: The Kinect is a little marvel of technology that has been released to the masses. This session will delve into foundational concepts surrounding this little gadget and describe Microsoft's Kinect API in a user friendly manner. Attendees will learn how to access the device's depth, camera, and skeletal information to create novel user interfaces to their software.

m:properties.d:title: The Full Stack Creating an integrated real-world Windows Phone application with ASP.NET MVC3, OData, WCF, & Entity Framework.
m:properties.d:description: Creation of a real-world Windows Phone application provides the context for this in-depth exploration of the full .NET Stack that will give attendees the insights needed to stitch together complex data-driven Silverlight and Windows Phone applications Jesse Liberty and Jon Galloway, members of the Developer Guidance Team at Microsoft are uniquely capable of demonstrating how to work around the pain points, avoid the pitfalls and fill in the blanks where documentation is scarce; and their ability to make deep technical information accessible and entertaining makes this a not-to-miss presentation.

m:properties.d:title: Your Spark Razored my NHaml: A comparison of popular ASP.NET MVC View Engines
m:properties.d:description: By now, if you've worked with ASP.NET MVC, you've worked with the default WebFormsViewEngine that may feel like a step back 10 years into Classic ASP 3.0. But there are other options available. ASP.NET MVC was designed to use other View Engines, allowing you to to keep the same Model and Controller while using code in your Views that doesn't bring back scary memories of COM. Spark, Razor, and NHaml are all popular View Engines that have each made a statement in ASP.NET MVC circles. Let's see what they are all about, how they compare, and how they stack up to the default engine.

m:properties.d:title: XCopy is Dead: .NET Deployment Strategies that Work
m:properties.d:description: Back in 1995, when we first started deploying web sites, the copy command was enough. Our web sites only consisted of a static HTML file and a few graphics of animated lava lamps. But our systems are more complex now; instead of a dozen files being uploaded through FTP to a single web server, we have hundreds of files spread across multiple load-balanced web servers, dozens of applications interwoven in a tiered server architecture, and an expectation that it can be deployed error-free without impacting our stringent SLAs. When a tool is no longer sufficient to perform the task at hand, it is time to find a better tool. XCopy is dead; it is time for strategies that work.

m:properties.d:title: Architectural Patterns for the Cloud
m:properties.d:description: Enough mushy, baby talk about the cloud. Let's roll up our sleeves and talk about some real patterns for how to use the cloud in the real world. Hint: As much as some vendors want you to think so, it doesn't require you to move everything to the cloud. Leave with some concrete ways to use the cloud in your existing world.

m:properties.d:title: How to move your app to the cloud
m:properties.d:description: Ok, so your boss says to port your app to the cloud so they can put a new bullet on their marketing brochure. No problem you say. We will look at the five things you need to do to migrate you cloud, make your boss happy, and retire to a private island in the Pacific. ** Island not provided.

m:properties.d:title: Scale your app with a distributed cache
m:properties.d:description: Sometimes, to improve performance all you have to do is add a cache. Microsoft has finally shipped 'Velocity' and called it the really catchy name Windows Server AppFabric Cache. We will look at how it works, how to install it, and how to leverage it in your ASP.NET application.

m:properties.d:title: Evolutionary Database Design with Fluent Migrator
m:properties.d:description: Today, with sophisticated version control systems like Git and Mercurial at our disposal, developers have an unprecedented level of control over the way their codebases evolve. In contrast, database change management feels like a second-class citizen. Emailing database backups to team members doesn't scale, and Visual Studio database projects just feel crufty. But there's another way. In this presentation, Brian will show you how to take control of your schema changes using migrations, and how this can take the pain out of working with databases on a team.

m:properties.d:title: NHIbernate, FluentNHibernate and the Repository Pattern in 75 Minutes or Less
m:properties.d:description: In this session we will discuss ORMs, how and why they are becoming so popular, and how to use them effectively. I will show you how to set up NHibernate, use FluentNHibernate to create mappings in code and use the Repository pattern to create a robust, easily maintainable data access layer.

m:properties.d:title: Need Some Cache? Redis In-Depth
m:properties.d:description: Redis is an exciting NoSQL offering. It allows you to decide if you want the blazingly fast response times of a pure in-memory caching solution or if you want to go slightly slower and have the assurance of the cache being persisted in case of failure. It offers a wide array of storage and retrieval options in addition to the key/value method standard to many NoSQL products. In this session we'll look into the depths of Redis. We'll go through its RESTful and binary access methods, different serialization options it allows, and a large proportion of its commands. Finally we'll wrap up with some benchmarking exercises and use case discussions. If you've wondered what Redis can do, this is the talk for you.

m:properties.d:title: Advanced Configuration of WCF Data Services for Producing OData
m:properties.d:description: Going beyond the simple WCF Data Service is key to building and producing valuable OData feeds that give users rich experiences as well as their developers the security and performance they demand. This track will give deep knowledge into the configuration and extensibility of the WCF Data Service/OData feed. It will also teach developers to secure their feeds through multiple user authentications such as OAuth, Windows and Forms Authentication.

m:properties.d:title: Consuming OData with the WCF Data Services Client Library and Silverlight/WPF
m:properties.d:description: Consuming OData from Silverlight and Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF) is much easier than most developers know using the updated WCF Data Services client library. Chris Woodruff demonstrates how to use OData while architecting application with the Model-View-ViewModel (MVVM) pattern and also does a deep dive into the WCF Data Services client library to show the capabilities it offers developers for their software projects.

m:properties.d:title: Semantic Markup: What, Why, and How"
m:properties.d:description: Semantic markup is markup that is descriptive of the content which it represents. Semantic markup is easily recognizable by both a browser and a person. The tags we use in our markup should not be used for their presentation value; instead tags should describe the content they contain. This moves us closer to separating our content from our presentation. After all, presentation should be controlled using CSS, not markup. In this presentation we will discuss the benefits of semantic markup and demonstrate how to get starting moving in that direction using real-world examples.

m:properties.d:title: Using and Optimizing jQuery Selectors
m:properties.d:description: jQuery has become a well-known JavaScript library. Examples abound online demonstrating how to use jQuery to accomplish a particular task. But while there are many ways to accomplish a particular task, they may not all be very efficient. In this presentation, we'll look at selectors in jQuery and how to use them in the most optimal way.

m:properties.d:title: Beyond Fast, Good and Cheap: Finding our priorities in the face of uncertainty.
m:properties.d:description: How do we balance building the right thing with building it well? In this presentation we will examine this question at three levels of focus: I Defining The Goal II Clarifying The Guidelines III Implementing The Practice This session will be an interactive discussion of the values, compromises and practices of successful software development from a practitioner's perspective.

m:properties.d:title: Add Spatial Capabilities to Your .NET Apps
m:properties.d:description: Due to the pervasiveness of GPS data, today's developers are being asked to incorporate geospatial information into their data-driven applications, often with no budget for procuring GIS software. SQL Server 2008 provides rich spatial support by means of the new Geometry and Geography data types, but some enterprises may not use SQL Server, or may be slow to upgrade their database platforms until years after a product release. There is still hope" .NET developers without access to SQL Server 2008 can still incorporate these new data types into their applications no SQL Server required" Not only will this solve an immediate need using Microsoft-supported technology, but also provides an upgrade path to using SQL Server 2008 for more advanced querying support. In addition, developers can also utilize Virtual Earth technology to provide an interactive geocoding and visualization story to their end users.

m:properties.d:title: Anti-Patterns in T-SQL
m:properties.d:description: This session will discuss the pitfalls of common anti-patterns covering the design phase through the maintenance phase, as well as the appropriate solution or alternative implementations. Anti-Pattern: "Separation of Concerns" Inherited from .NET programming, this anti-pattern involves storing your set of data to be manipulated into a temporary table/table variable, using multiple set-based operations on it, and then updating the original data. Commonly this is done in a database without concurrency checking introducing the likelihood of data integrity issues. Anti-Pattern: Chaining "re-usable" stored procedures together via a server-side cursor to perform more complex operations Inherited from object-oriented programming where it is ideal to use many small, re-usable methods to accomplish complex operations. Commonly this is found where a procedural mind set is prevalent, by both .NET and T-SQL programmers. Although acceptable for initial development efforts (perhaps just a spike), it does not scale well in T-SQL. Anti-Pattern: Relying solely on calling code (e.g. .NET-based middle-tier/business layer) to handle transactions, error handling, and logging Each T-SQL stored procedure is a stand-alone piece of code. As such, one must not assume that it would always be called by a parent process that will wrap it in a transaction (if appropriate), handle any errors, and provide logging facilities where appropriate. Each stored procedure must be responsible for handling its own actions. Anti-Pattern: Assuming the data model/database code is "self-documenting" A database diagram combined with a good, consistent naming convention is a good start, but it is not nearly sufficient. Tables, columns, relationships, and other constraints should have descriptions that include information beyond what can be discerned by the metadata. Using Enum-style views instead of magic numbers and/or strings can be a huge benefit: improves readability, makes it less fragile, and reduces maintenance cost/effort. Anti-Pattern: Not taking the time to properly model at every change This anti-pattern typically occurs during the maintenance phase but it also occurs near an approaching deadline (or the end of a sprint). Tables and/or columns are just added quickly on an as-needed basis without the taking the time to ensure it is properly modeled. Although it saves time initially, it frequently piles on technical debt. Anti-Pattern: Writing code that is not testable and/or difficult to debug This anti-pattern isn't acceptable in any code, but in the T-SQL occurrences it translates to stored procedures that return multiple result sets, not having an optional "debug" parameter, and not having configurable levels of logging. It also includes not having sufficient documentation where the function/stored procedure is complex. Anti-Pattern: Writing the one "search" stored procedure or table valued function to rule them all Creating a generic, search-type stored procedure or TVF that involves 3 or more optional parameters, frequently with no required parameters, is a future performance issue. It will likely perform very well with a small data set, but when the number of optional parameters or the data set size is increased, it will begin to perform poorly when certain combinations of parameters/values are used. Smaller, more focused, search procedures or a dynamic SQL procedure will perform consistently better. Anti-Pattern: "Re-creating the wheel"/"Rolling your own" This anti-pattern is not restricted to T-SQL. In .NET, a server-side control may be created to avoid the cost of a 3rd-party control or because the team thinks they can write it better (more features or faster performance) or quicker than they can research the market and acquire the funding. In T-SQL, it may be a developer creating a pseudo-cursor rather than using a server-side cursor. After all, cursors are evil right? _Client-side_ cursors are evil, but server-side cursors, with the appropriate optimizations, are occasionally the appropriate solution. Pseudo-cursors frequently perform worse than server-side cursors. Another common instance of this pattern involves writing your own queuing tables and code rather than using Service Broker. The impending concurrency and reliability issues frequently don't rear their ugly head during development and testing. Anti-Pattern: Using large, complex views as the primary API to the database In an effort to speed development or to shortcut documenting the data model, large, complex views are frequently created to assist junior SQL and .NET developers. While originally these views may have been designed for a single silo of information, they are frequently joined to one another to solve unforeseen, or more complex, business requirements. They also frequently get nested multiple levels deep as development and/or maintenance activities continue. It is only a matter of time before the performance issues begin to crop up and the more usages of DISTINCT, aggregates, scalar functions, and SORT BY that are involved, the quicker they appear. Anti-Pattern: Relying on ad-hoc data updates to manage data-driven application configuration This anti-pattern usually arises from not allocating enough time to create the management UI's or always pushing their priority lower than everything else. Although the solution could be just a very simple GUI calling existing, tested, stored procedures, reliance on ad-hoc T-SQL inserts/updates/deletes is common. This introduces the opportunity of human error, not only in the development of the ad-hoc script, but also in the execution. Human error and/or the lack of complete database constraints can cause data integrity issues all too easily. Anti-Pattern: Waiting until performance is critical before tuning the database/"Throw more hardware at it" This anti-pattern is brought into existence primarily by "lack": lack of funding, lack of priority, lack of time, lack of a pro-active mind set, and/or lack of expertise. Throwing more hardware at the performance problems will only buy you a limited amount of time. It will become progressively more expensive if serious performance tuning/redesign efforts aren't undertaken as soon as possible. Avoid this pitfall from the beginning, design and code for performance throughout the application's lifecycle. Instrument the application and monitor its performance degradation and pro-actively tune the code, design, and data access paths. Remember, it's not a matter of if performance degradation will occur, it's when. Get ahead and stay ahead.

m:properties.d:title: Creating High-Performance Dynamic Types in C#
m:properties.d:description: Using the dynamic keyword in C# can make your applications really crawl, if you aren't careful. Understanding how the dynamic keyword works under the covers helps you to know when you can use it safely. In this talk, we'll dive deep into the implementation of the CallSites that are emitted by the C# compiler. We'll look at how performance problems can be avoided by following a few simple rules. Then we'll dive into the IDynamicMetaObjectProvider interface, learning how to create high performance, dynamic types that can make your code much more fluent and fast than you may have imagined possible.

m:properties.d:title: Building Tiny Devices with the .NET Micro Framework
m:properties.d:description: The Microsoft .NET Micro Framework (NETMF) is an abstraction of the larger .NET Framework that runs on tiny, embeddable devices. And it's completely open source" In this session, you'll learn about the architecture of NETMF and the miniature computers that run it. During the highly interactive discussion, you'll watch as the presenter builds a device using C# that accepts instructions through an embedded web server, collects measurements from various sensors and forwards them to a database on a mesh network. And it will all run on a 9 volt battery. Come see how the power of the .NET Framework has been totally minified"

m:properties.d:title: Managing Agile Projects
m:properties.d:description: Most corporations are still fairly traditionally structured even though many software development teams are heading full steam into modern, highly iterative, agile software development techniques. This leaves management stuck coping with an organizational and technical paradigm shift that traditional project management practices are inadequate to handle. In the highly iterative, fast-paced environment characteristic of these modern software development projects, traditional approaches to budgeting, testing, quality assurance, requirements gathering, scheduling and estimating break down. Managers trying to encourage best practices as recommended by CMMI and SPICE find themselves at odds with developers trying to adopt best practices as recommended by the agile manifesto. This tutorial explains practical ways to adapt the formal, heavy weight, process control inherent in CMMI recommendations to the lighter weight, more flexible practices of agile development.

m:properties.d:title: Dancing with Pigs - Elaborating Scrum Interactions
m:properties.d:description: There are many ways to choreograph the activities within a sprint, but all of them involve intricate, dance like, interactions among testers [1] , product owners, other team members and chickens. Becoming good at agile development is a little like learning to dance. Some of us are naturally born dancers and learn quickly and seemingly effortlessly. Others of us struggle for quite a while to get our two left feet coordinating effectively with the rest of the team. But natural or not, every team member needs to become good at the agile dance. This article hopes to help you become a better dancer by exploring six principles of agile interactions. More specifically, we will focus on those interactions necessary to discovering and elaborating requirements within the context of the Scrum framework.

m:properties.d:title: Producing and Consuming OData in an Silverlight and Windows Phone 7 application.
m:properties.d:description: Learn how to Produce and Consume an OData DataSource starting from File-New Project. In this session, we will produce an OData Datasource and query it using the browser and LinqPAD. Once we have an understanding of how to produce an OData DataSource, we will consume it using Silverlight and Windows Phone 7. Part 1: We will create a oData Service using SQL Server Compact 4.0 Edition. After the oData Service is created, we will navigate to the url and see how we can use the browser to display and filter the data. After that we will take LinqPad (free edition) and query the data using Linq. Part 2: Consume the Data using Silverlight 4 Application. Setting up the Source Data to retrieving it in our application and binding the results to multiple textblock controls. Part 3: Consume the Data using WP7: Explaining all the missing parts to consuming an oData Feed in a Windows Phone 7 Application using the Panorama Template.

m:properties.d:title: Crossing the boundaries of web applications with OpenSocial
m:properties.d:description: When OpenSocial was first introduced three years ago, the main goal was to create an open and distributed alternative to the closed off Facebook platform for social apps. Since then much has happened: The specification as well as the OpenSocial foundation behind it have majored and powerful new features and concepts have been introduced. More and more social networks are implementing OpenSocial containers, allowing developers to reach over 900 million users with one social app. Additionally education organizations and enterprise companies like IBM, SAP, SurfNET or Atlassian are seeing the benefits of an open standard to connect their applications more tightly and to open them up to other developers. In this presentation I will introduce you to the OpenSocial specification and walk you through a live-programming example to show you how easy it is to connect an existing PHP web application to enterprise products such as Google Mail or Confluence and social networks alike, integrating it right into your user's existing tools and workflows.

m:properties.d:title: Distributed Identities with OpenID
m:properties.d:description: The era of many separated logins and identities in the web is slowly coming to an end. Currently many of the big players are spurring this on with their own proprietary solutions, but open standards are starting to get more support as well with OpenID being the most promising one. In this session I will start off discussing what identity means offline and online and the ways one uses different identities quite naturally. Based on this I will introduce different concepts of how you can represent your identities in the web, where current problems are and what solutions different players came up with. Besides the currently wide spread proprietary solutions, such as Facebook Connect or Twitter Anywhere, I will highlight OpenID as an open and distributed alternative. I will show how OpenID works for users and developers, where it currently fails and how OpenID is planned to evolve in the future through emerging specifications like OAuth2 and OpenID Connect. Additionally I will give an outlook on how browser vendors could possibly influence the identity game drastically by better authorization support such as the use of client side certificates.

m:properties.d:title: Opening up the Social Web - Standards that are bridging the Islands
m:properties.d:description: Social networks are not closed off to the rest of the web anymore. Various standards like ActivityStreams, PubSubHubbub, WebFinger, OpenSocial, Salmon, OEmbed, XAuth or OExchange are emerging to open them up to other websites and projects like Diaspora or Status.NET are already using them in production. I will introduce these protocols, show how they work together, how you can benefit from them and give an outlook on how they can possibly change the world of social networks.

m:properties.d:title: Do I Really Need a Mobile App, or is a Mobile-Friendly Website Enough?
m:properties.d:description: Mobile apps are the hottest trend in tech right now, leaving many companies struggling to create a mobile strategy for their products or services. When defining this strategy, the question of do I really need a mobile app is the first barrier that needs to be crossed. Deciding whether a mobile app is truly necessary is the first, and perhaps the most important decision. In this session, I will discuss why a company might truly need a custom mobile application, and when updating a portion of an existing web site to be mobile device-friendly may be the more appropriate solution.

m:properties.d:title: Design for Developers
m:properties.d:description: As developers we sometimes miss the importance of a very well designed application. Over the last 3 years, I have had the chance to work with a very talented designer who has taught me the basics that all developers should know. In this session I will be sharing these techniques. Techniques such as picking color schemes and typography, table less web design, CSS tricks, and image editing basics using Adobe Fireworks and Paint .net. Walking out of this session, you will have gained a basic knowledge of design/usability/accessibility and have the ability to start getting away from the battleship gray applications developers tend to create.

m:properties.d:title: Distributed Version Control with Mercurial: A new way to work
m:properties.d:description: What's wrong with the way we've been using source control? Nothing actually, but new tools have come along which empower developers and enable workflows that were not possible before. In this session, we'll examine the reasons that distributed version control systems (DVCS) were created. We will step through the flow of changes when using a DVCS. We'll discuss the DVCS alternatives available with demonstrations using Mercurial.

m:properties.d:title: Introduction to GPGPU Development using CUDA
m:properties.d:description: Much has been made in recent years about the multi-core explosion and the paradigm shift that developers are facing. In concert with this change, we are seeing a dramatic increase in the use of hybrid architectures (combination of traditional CPU and specialized processing boards). The most common combination of hybrid architecture is the CPU and GPU. In this session we'll provide an introduction to writing code to run on the GPU, we'll look at developer tools in Visual Studio to assist in this process, and we'll discuss various applications and approaches to consider when looking to leverage the GPU in your applications.

m:properties.d:title: A Comparison of Windows Azure and Amazon Web Services
m:properties.d:description: Often when you talk with someone about cloud computing, or when you are evaluating the cloud for your application, the advice you get is slanted to one platform or the other. Generally, this is due to the fact that most cloud experts know a lot about their particular platform of choice and aren't overly familiar with other offerings. Join us as we take a side-by-side walk through the features of both the Amazon and Microsoft offerings, and discuss various strengths and weaknesses of the platforms as well as their similarities and distinctives.

m:properties.d:title: Managing the mentoring process
m:properties.d:description: Join us as we openly discuss the best mentoring methods of increasing technical and inner-office political skills aka "social intelligence". Find out the positives and drawbacks of the various methods and the difficulties in dealing with technical employees and their unique social skill sets. Geared for the entry to mid-level manager and project manager.

m:properties.d:title: Learning Messaging Patterns with RabbitMQ
m:properties.d:description: Messaging patterns are a great way to write integrated and distributed systems. RabbitMQ provides a powerful and feature rich messaging broker based on the AMQP specification. This session will cover RabbitMQ basics and demonstrate how it can be used in cross-language communication between .Net and Python.

m:properties.d:title: Getting Started With Node.js
m:properties.d:description: Node.js has fueled an explosion of developer creativity and enthusiasm but what is it? In this session we will explore Node.js server side JavaScript and a few of the powerful capabilities it enables developers to take advantage of. Want to see a simple http server that's 10 lines of code? Want to write a working telnet chat server prototype in a few minutes? Curious as to what the fuss over server-side JavaScript is all about? If you've never used Node.js and are curious to learn more, this session is for you.

m:properties.d:title: The Right Introduction for SharePoint Developers
m:properties.d:description: "What in the world have I gotten myself into?" "I'm so confused" "I hate SharePoint with a burning passion of a million suns"" If you are just getting started in SharePoint development or architecture and have ever uttered those words, then this is the session for you. What should every developer be aware of before diving head first into SharePoint? Being a talented .NET developer does not directly translate to being a SharePoint Developer. The learning curve can be huge and the environment taxing. Mark Rackley designed this session as the session he wished he would have seen when he started SharePoint Development. In this session you will learn: A greater understanding of what SharePoint is and how it's structured including a crash course in Logical Architecture, Taxonomy, Governance and why these topics are so important in SharePoint. What steps to take in order to become a SharePoint developer and a jumpstart on getting started down that path. Why the SharePoint community is unique and important. To avoid NOT using OOB SharePoint

m:properties.d:title: SharePoint Development: Overcoming Hurdles and Avoiding Pain
m:properties.d:description: Why am I getting a security error?" "Why does my code work sometimes, but not others?" "I wonder if McDonalds is hiring." Writing custom code in SharePoint opens up unlimited possibilities but also throws many hurdles in your way that will slow you down if you don't take them into account. So, before giving up and searching for careers in the fast food industry, equip yourself with the knowledge you need to succeed in writing custom code for SharePoint. In this session you will learn: Best practices for avoiding performance issues Best practices for avoiding memory leaks Best practices for elevating privileges Avoid not disposing of SP Objects

m:properties.d:title: Learning to Relax with CouchBase
m:properties.d:description: NoSQL (non-relational) database engines provide non-traditional persistence solutions that scale horizontally. CouchBase (formerly CouchDB) is a RESTful, JSON document store written in Erlang. This session will cover basic NoSQL terminology, talk about CouchDB's features and demo CouchDB usage in .Net with an open source library, Relax.

m:properties.d:title: MongoDB For the SQL Server Developer
m:properties.d:description: As a SQL Server Developer you have probably already heard the hype around the NoSQL movement, but you haven't had a chance to see what the fuss is all about. Or maybe you just haven't had the time to figure out where to start. Well, this is the session for you. In this session we will learn about the easy to use, open source, document database, MongoDB, and we will do it in a way that will leverage your SQL skills. Come learn how, and more importantly, when, to use a NoSQL database, and even learn how to use your new NoSQL skills back in SQL Server.

m:properties.d:title: Building RESTful Services with the New WCF HTTP Programming Model
m:properties.d:description: If you are building for the web and the cloud, then you know that HTTP is important. WCF is no stranger to HTTP. Since .NET 3.5, Microsoft has been continually delivering capabilities in the platform to enable developers to expose services as resources over HTTP. Now the WCF team is looking to raise the bar several notches and provide a first class programming model for HTTP in WCF. The new WCF HTTP programming model will: Let you have complete control over HTTP. Support a multitude of media types (formats) i..e XML, JSON, ATOM, OData, and custom formats including those that are hypermedia driven. Give you full access to your Uri and headers Provide richer support for web frameworks like jQuery. In this session we will review these new features, and demonstrate how to take advantage of them when building RESTful services with WCF.

m:properties.d:title: Mobile Smackdown
m:properties.d:description: If you're considering getting into mobile development, this is the session you don't want to miss. Mobile experts on Android, Windows Phone, and iPhone will spend 15 minutes developing a specific application on their respective platform LIVE during the session. Come to root on your favorite, but take an opportunity to find out just how easy it is to build applications for all three ecosystems. Get here early, this room will be rowdy.

m:properties.d:title: Debugging Tips and Tricks with Visual Studio 2010
m:properties.d:description: Debuggings is not just setting a few breakpoints and pressing F5. In this session you will learn all about the new debugging features in Visual Studio 2010. We will also deep dive into Intellitrace, how it works, and why you should use it. We'll look at how Intellitrace can make use of TFS, Team Build, and Source and Symbol Servers to enhance your debugging efforts, and you'll learn how Intellitrace eliminates the "no repro" scenario.

m:properties.d:title: Testing Tools in Visual Studio 2010
m:properties.d:description: Visual Studio 2010 delivers a new crop of testing tools that raise the bar for testing, as well as provide testers with everything they need to do their job right. And the best thing is, they don't even have to go into Visual Studio 2010 to use them" In this session we will look at some of the new testing tools available with Visual Studio 2010, including the Manual Test Runner, Test Cases, and Coded UI Tests. Once you watch a test run using the Manual Test Recorder, and see all the information it collects for you, as well as the video playback, you'll wonder how you ever lived without these tools"

m:properties.d:title: Diagnostics and Analysis Tools to Improve Software Quality
m:properties.d:description: As applications become more complex and pressures to decrease costs increase, we need tools to facilitate reducing the turn-around time for testers and developers to find and fix bugs. Microsoft Test and Lab Manager enables testers to collect more detailed diagnostic data during a test run leading to higher quality bugs that provide more insight to the developers on what actually went wrong when the bug occurred. With the addition of Test Strips, testers can generate automation as an artifact of their test runs helping to not only increase coverage of the application, but reducing the time it takes to manually test the application. Test Impact Analysis helps developers test the right automated tests from within Visual Studio, while testers know what the right set of tests to prioritize and run are given recent changes introduced by the development organization.

m:properties.d:title: Virtualizing Your Testing with Lab Management 2010
m:properties.d:description: This session will provide an overview of the new Microsoft visual Studio Lab Management tool, an integrated platform that provides end-to-end support for virtual lab and environment management. I will demonstrate how to use Lab Management as a means of automating the creation and tear down of virtual environments for testing purposes. This session will also demonstrate how to deploy to VM environments during builds and how to roll back your virtual test environments to a known good state. See how to facilitate a robust testing lifecycle using Microsoft Lab Management.

m:properties.d:title: The CAP Theorem and its Consequences
m:properties.d:description: In 2000, Eric Brewer postulated the CAP Theorem. It defines the behavior of distributed systems. Since then, we have based several architectures on this work. The CAP Theorem states that any subsystem can have only two of these three attributes: * Consistency * Availability * Partition Tolerance Consistency is the property that two users see the same state. Availability means that a node gives a meaningful response in a reasonable period of time. Partition Tolerance allows a system to continue operating in the face of repeated message loss. If you can have only two, which two do you choose? Traditional architectures have chosen consistency over partition tolerance. New architectures are reversing that trend. We will discuss architectural decisions, such as: * Eventual Consistency * Event Sourcing * Command Query Responsibility Segregation I will demonstrate ways of coding these architectures, and the benefits and drawbacks of each technique.

m:properties.d:title: Correspondence: Building Occasionally Connected Windows Phone Apps
m:properties.d:description: Phones are personal devices, so users expect their data to be local. But they are also collaborative devices, so users expect them to talk to each other. An occasionally connected Windows Phone application is the best of both worlds. It stores personal data locally for instant access. And it synchronizes with remote services for collaboration. Correspondence is an open source library specifically designed to make it easy to build occasionally connected applications. When you design your data model using its DSL, it generates both a local database and a network protocol. Then it gives you an object model to code against that seamlessly bridges the two worlds. Not only will I demonstrate a collaborative Windows Phone application, but I'll teach you how to write one. You start with the data model, written in a Domain Specific Language called Factual. Then you expose that model through a View Model layer. Data bind your View Model to the UI, and your application is complete. When the user makes a change, it is both stored to the local database and published to the server. Changes made by other users are automatically pushed to the phone. Through the magic of data binding, the user is instantly notified of the change.

m:properties.d:title: APIs That Make Things Happen - WebHooks and the Evented Web
m:properties.d:description: WebHooks are simple: something happens, a URL is requested and code is executed. While the concept is simple, the result is powerful real-time capabilities for your application that are easy to implement. This session will cover what WebHooks are, who is already using them, why push is better than poll, why you should care and how you can start using them in your apps today.

m:properties.d:title: Leaving the Window Open
m:properties.d:description: Window functions are a way to apply aggregates to parts of a result set. Running totals, rankings, averages can all be applied to a subset of the data. Understanding how and when to use windowing functions can add substantial power and performance to your application. Computing running totals, averages by state or group, and other complex aggregations are not easy to implement in many relational databases. Thankfully, many relational databases include support for window functions. Window functions are an extension to the ANSI SQL standard. More than just another part of SQL, window functions enable complex ranking, ordering, and other aggregations over a subset of rows in a query. Understanding the capabilities of window functions lets you extend application functionality, build rich and complex queries, and reduce overhead in the application tier.

m:properties.d:title: SQL Refactoring
m:properties.d:description: Refactoring SQL is not like refactoring application code. This talk will demonstrate proven SQL refactoring techniques that will help you identify where performance gains can be made, apply quick fixes, improve readability, and help you quickly locate places to make sweeping performance improvements. Jeremiah Peschka has years of hands on experience tuning SQL applications for performance, throughput, and concurrency.

m:properties.d:title: Cross Platform Command-Query (CQRS)
m:properties.d:description: Discussion and demo of a CQRS (Command-Query Responsibility Separation) architecture on multiple platforms connected to each other across an enterprise service bus (MassTransit). We will discuss the use of a scalable, multi-platform messaging system for events the cross process boundaries or might exist in a distributed environment. We will be demonstrating a light weight Rails website using Masstransit.rb, which will communicate with an existing back-end written in .NET, showing how everything can be cleanly interconnected.

m:properties.d:title: Take the Magic out of File-Based Data Stores
m:properties.d:description: We'll discuss the planning and development process of Cashbox, a completely managed document store written for .NET that sits within a single process. From the first steps of understanding the problem and discovering how to address it to finally writing a custom storage engine to replace the stop-gap storage solutions used at first. This will discuss most things at a high level, using code merely as a way to point out ways to address problems and discuss approaches used.

m:properties.d:title: Lightweight Data Access in .NET
m:properties.d:description: NHibernate, Entity Framework and a whole host of other complex ORMs are available for .NET but what if you just need to move data from a database to an application quickly and simply? In this session we will tour some of the lighter weight data access technologies including Simple.Data, Massive and WebMatrix.Data. If you don't need every single feature under the sun, these may be just the data access you are looking for. See how you can build well architected and secure applications with these technologies without having to spend valuable development time implementing a complex solution to a simple problem.
