m:properties.d:title: Reactive Extensions for Javascript
m:properties.d:description: The Reactive Extensions allow developers to build composabile, asynchronous event driven methods over observable collections. In web applications, you can use this same model in client side processing using the RxJs framework. We'll show you how you can take advantage of this framework to simplify your complex asynchronous client side operations.

m:properties.d:title: Asynchronous Programming Models with .Net
m:properties.d:description: While .Net 4 added parallel programming capabilities, these tools primarily help when your application is CPU bound. In many cases, parallel processing doesn't address IO Latency issues. In these cases, we need to provide the perception of responsive applications by using asynchronous programming tools. We will explore some of these options including Delegates, Callbacks, Iterators, Observers, and the new C# Async keywords.

m:properties.d:title: Streamlined Object Modeling, DDD, and Event Sourcing
m:properties.d:description: Join Michael Brown as he demonstrates a forgotten approach to software design. In this session, we will discuss a fusion of techniques to help developers discover a richer model of a problem domain and apply that model both for development as well as requirements gathering. Learning this technique will help you become more confident in speaking with stakeholders and help you identify unspoken requirements that the experts might not realize are there. The topics we will cover include: The four archetypes of object models The Domain-Neutral Component (DNC) and its significance Using the DNC to discover missing objects from your model Why junction tables are more significant than they first appear Evolving your object model to create a fluent, ubiquitous language In addition, there will be time for a demonstration of the technique, come prepared to interact.

m:properties.d:title: MVVM Unleashed
m:properties.d:description: In his book "Refactoring to Patterns" Joshua Kerievsky states clearly why he wrote it:

m:properties.d:title: The Utility Belt for Windows Azure
m:properties.d:description: Batman had some great toys on his utility belt. It seemed like he had a perfect tool for almost any situation" Even though we aren't fighting crime and aren't billionaires (at least I'm not) that doesn't mean we can't also have a great utility belt of tools to help us in our profession. This presentation will cover several tools for people working with Windows Azure that will help you manage, monitor and work with your services in the cloud. We'll cover both free and commercial tools.

m:properties.d:title: Evaluating Scrum - Is It Right For You?
m:properties.d:description: Scrum is increasing in popularity. A recent survey shows that 53% of new projects use some form of Agile, with Scrum being the most popular. This session will introduce you to the fundamentals of Scrum and is a good choice for persons having to interact with a scrum team or persons thinking about using Scrum on an upcoming project. You will learn the responsibilities of each of the basic scrum roles of Scrum Master, Product Owner, and the cross-functional team. You will also learn the basic scrum process, and the artifacts used to manage and document a Scrum project. Perhaps most importantly you will learn the driving principles behind Scrum and how they lead to helping organizations meet and exceed their goals.

m:properties.d:title: Develop IT: Intro to PowerShell
m:properties.d:description: This session is good for both developers and IT pros who want to get started with PowerShell but have not worked with it at all. In this session, we will look at the basics of PowerShell - from installation to grammar, aliases, piping, functions and profiles. We will use examples that are practical from both a developer's point of view and from an IT professional's point of view.

m:properties.d:title: Develop IT: Extending PowerShell with Custom Cmdlets and Modules
m:properties.d:description: PowerShell is a scripting language that takes advantage of working in a shell and being able to access .NET libraries. In this session, you will learn how you can write your own cmdlets to extend PowerShell to meet your business needs and distribute them in PowerShell 2.0, using your C# skills and Visual Studio 2010.

m:properties.d:title: Erlang: an intro for .NET developers
m:properties.d:description: Would you like to build massively parallel, distributed, fault-tolerant, cross-platform, easily maintainable systems with less code and look cool doing it? If so, the opensource programming language Erlang has some real sweet spots for you. If you're unfamiliar with Erlang you may be surprised to learn how battle tested it is: Facebook's chat backend, CouchDB , RabbitMQ , GitHub's backend and Amazon's SimpleDB are all written in Erlang, and every phone call you make is likely helped along by some Erlang somewhere. So how does a functional programming language with Prolog and telecom roots solve so many of the big problems that Enterprisey languages famously stink at? How do I (as a C# developer) even get started with Erlang? Can't wait to show you. Is it scary? Heck no. How do I integrate Erlang with my .NET code? Will learning Erlang make me a better .NET developer?

m:properties.d:title: Continuous Integration with TFS
m:properties.d:description: Learn the Ins and Outs of TFS Team Build, starting with Build Controllers and Agents and then all the way through to the new Workflow-based templates. We will go over how to create custom activities, and much more in order to take full advantage of TFS's powerful build system and empower your team.

m:properties.d:title: Succeeding with Scrum
m:properties.d:description: Scrum is not a new concept but it has gained a lot of popularity in the last few years. It is a very powerful agile project management methodology that, when used correctly, can help your team deliver better software faster than before. We will start with a brief overview of the process and look at some techniques and tools that will help you succeed, as well as common pitfalls that you should avoid. Come prepared for an interactive session where you will be encouraged to share your experiences with Scrum.

m:properties.d:title: Developing Robust Client Side Web Applications with Object Oriented JavaScript
m:properties.d:description: JavaScript is the cornerstone of a good foundation as a web application developer. As today's apps get more complex, and more logic migrates client side, the need for Object Oriented Javascript has grown. This talk will cover when to use JavaScript objects, and how to build them using common design patterns. Also, we will be learning about polymorphism, encapsulation, inheritance, constructors, and helper functions using the JQuery library.

m:properties.d:title: Your OS is Going the Way of the Dodo
m:properties.d:description: Your operating system has fundamental flaws for today's computing needs. Google has created a full featured, more secure and more resilient Operating System. This session will show you the Google's Chrome operating system and explain why Windows, Macintosh, and Linux will soon be legacy operating systems.

m:properties.d:title: Creating a Culture of Change
m:properties.d:description: As highly engaged developers we sometimes are dismayed by the apparent inertia exhibited by others around us. We wish we could somehow transplant our passion into our co-workers and managers and get them as excited as we are about all the new developments in application development. Often times our enthusiasm is misinterpreted as "Shiny Object Syndrome" and our pleas for change denied. Is there a way to bring change to teams and organizations that have been "stuck" in what seems like the dark ages for years? Yes, and in this session you'll learn the tools and techinques to do just that.

m:properties.d:title: Introduction to Continuous Integration using TeamCity
m:properties.d:description: Continuous Integration (CI) is a valuable software development practice, yet many teams do not implement CI. In this presentation, we will talk about the benefits of continuous integration and how TeamCity makes it easy to get started. We will examine build configurations inspired by real world requirements that show how to build code, run tests, and prepare code for deployment. By the end of this presentation, you will be able to start doing continuous integration with TeamCity.

m:properties.d:title: jQuery On The Go
m:properties.d:description: jQuery has revolutionalized the way we build applications for the web. Now, with the alpha release of jQuery Mobile, we will be able to harness the power of jQuery on our mobile devices. Build single mobile applications that run across multiple devices. In this talk, Kevin Griffin will guide you through what's available in the jQuery Mobile.

m:properties.d:title: Consuming REST APIs in .NET with RestSharp
m:properties.d:description: RestSharp is a popular, simple REST and HTTP API client that takes the pain out of consuming HTTP in .NET, Mono, MonoTouch, Mono for Android, Silverlight and Windows Phone 7. After a brief overview of the REST/HTTP landscape in .NET, we'll cover RestSharp's features and demonstrate some of the most common use cases. We'll also cover OAuth and using RestSharp on mobile platforms like MonoTouch and Windows Phone 7.

m:properties.d:title: Greenfield .NET Development with CQRS
m:properties.d:description: It's rare that you get a chance to build an applicaton the way you want to, from the ground up. If you did, what architectural choices would you make and why? Command Query Responsibility Segregation (CQRS) is a hot topic and has been described as crack for architecture addicts. This talk will look at why CQRS may be a good architectural choice for your project, how to use the NCQRS framework, and how this framework can be incorporated with ASP.NET MVC on the front-end and Azure on the back-end. This talk will also focus on the learning curve experienced when implementing an architectural style that bends the curve and is out of the mainstream of traditional application development.

m:properties.d:title: OData and jQuery - Peanut Butter Jelly Time
m:properties.d:description: You've created web sites and spruced them up with jQuery to improve your user experience. You've played around with WCF Data Services to create lists of data from your server. But what happens when you bring the two of them together. It's like peanut butter and jelly; peas and carrots; well, you get the idea. This talk will describe how to connect your jQuery-based web application with your OData data service. If time permits, we'll also look at binding your OData feed to interesting jQuery plug-ins like jqGrid.

m:properties.d:title: Functional C#
m:properties.d:description: This session will delve into the functional underpinnings that were introduced in C# 1.0 and show how they have evolved to produce some incredibly interesting constructs that can make your C# code more powerful and concise.

m:properties.d:title: Machine Learning for .NET
m:properties.d:description: The purpose of this session is to demystify the central ideas behind pattern recognition and machine learning by demonstrating two key elements of the same: namely classification and clustering. Most developers shy away from such algorithms simply because of their perceived difficulty while missing the inherent simplicity of these approaches. The first part of the session will demonstrate how a computer can learn from labeled examples in order to predict appropriate labels for future examples. The second portion will deal with learning the structure of data without having to know anything about it a priori. This introduction will include a demonstration of linear classification as well as a simple clustering algorithm called K-Means. The intent of the session is to empower advanced developers to learn certain techniques that will allow for exciting and novel features in any software they develop in the future.

m:properties.d:title: C# Design Patterns
m:properties.d:description: Instead of boring the audience with a multitude of slides, this session will feature live coding to illustrate some of the well known gang-of-four design patterns in C#. Attendees will not only be able to see a live demonstration of these patterns, but through the demonstrations will be empowered to find areas in their own software where these patterns will benefit the quality and re-usability of their code all in a highly interactive session.

m:properties.d:title: Using Nuget to Simplify Package Management
m:properties.d:description: NuGet is a Visual Studio extension that makes it easy to add, remove, and update libraries and tools in Visual Studio projects that use the .NET Framework. We'll open the session with a look at how to install and manage 3rd party libraries in you applications. We will then quickly turn to creating Nuget packages for distribution of your libraries and wrap up by creating a Nuget server for hosting internal libraries and dependencies within your organization.

m:properties.d:title: Using jQuery UI to Make your Sites Look and Work Better
m:properties.d:description: This session will drill into jQuery UI, a library built on top of jQuery that includes widgets, effects and mouse interactions that allow web developers to implement sophisticated features like themable controls, animations, and advanced interactions such as drag and drop. We'll look at several examples of jQuery UI such as content sliders, content rotators, themes and the ThemeRoller, Accordions, Modal Windows and much more. We'll start with a very quick intro to jQuery itself. Then cover different options for wiring your website with jQuery and jQuery UI. We'll take a whirlwind tour of all that is jQuery UI and then spend some time drilling deeper into a few examples. This session will also provide a variety of resources for working on your own with jQuery and jQuery UI as well as some resources for User Interface and User Experience design. This session requires no previous knowledge of jQuery or JavaScript.

m:properties.d:title: Design resources for Developers (making yourself a deseloper or devigner)
m:properties.d:description: There was a lot of conversation a year or two ago about how many web programmers ended up being responsible for the "design" of web sites even though they had no perceptible design skills even by their own standards. This session is geared towards the developer that could use a little help making sites look and work better. We'll look at resources for creating, stealing, buying and editing aesthetically pleasing websites and color schemes. We'll discuss how CSS can be used to create sites that can be easily and properly displayed on desktops, mobile devices and printers. We'll explore the developer tools built into modern browsers that allow us to analyze and tweak cosmetic issues. Additionally, we'll look at some jQuery Plugins that can give our sites unbelievably professional features with remarkably little effort. We'll wrap up by looking at resources for User Interface and User Experience patterns and resources that can be used to not only make your site better looking, but easier to use.

m:properties.d:title: datajs: A New Ingredient In Your Cross-Browser Kitchen
m:properties.d:description: datajs is a new cross-browser JavaScript library from Microsoft that supports data-centric web applications, and is small and fast. See how you can leverage the caching capability in datajs and what it can do with OData. Understand how datajs differs from Knockout. See how it behaves on the desktop and the device. You'll leave this session with an understanding of datajs and how to use it. You'll see how it can be a great new ingredient in your kitchen for working with data, and what great things you can create when you mix it with OData and HTML 5.

m:properties.d:title: Effective Data Visualization: The Ideas of Edward Tufte
m:properties.d:description: We spend much of our time collecting and analyzing data. That data is only useful if it can be displayed in a meaningful, understandable way. Yale professor Edward Tufte presented many ideas on how to effectively present data to an audience or end user. In this session, I will explain some of Tufte's most important guidelines about data visualization and how you can apply those guidelines to your own data. You will learn what to include, what to remove, and what to avoid in your charts, graphs, maps and other images that represent data.

m:properties.d:title: Get Your Auth On With Windows Azure AppFabric Access Control Service
m:properties.d:description: Looking for a mechanism to make it easier to authenticate and authorize users with in your sites and services? Want your applications to work seamlessly with Windows LiveID, Google, Yahoo", Facebook, enterprise identities from a single codebase? Take a look at Windows Azure AppFabric Access Control Service (ACS) and see how it can be a key building block for your applications. In this session you'll gain an understanding of how ACS can simplify your codebase provide a common mechanism to deal with identity in your applications. See ACS principles illustrated through many demos and discussions real-world experiences.

m:properties.d:title: Using StudioShell to Customize Visual Studio
m:properties.d:description: StudioShell is a deeply integrated PowerShell host available inside of Visual Studio 2010 and 2008. It's goal is to fundamentally change the way you interact with your IDE and your code. If you've ever implemented a Visual Studio extension, such as an add-in or a package, you know how convoluted this space has become. In a nutshell, you have to become an expert in your tooling if you want to change it. StudioShell exposes many of Visual Studio's extensibility points in a simple and consistent way, and it makes the Visual Studio DTE interactive and discoverable. What an add-in does in a compiled binary, StudioShell can accomplish with a one-liner. Come see the possibilities in an hour-long session of practical demonstration given my the author of StudioShell. Specifics include: exploring Visual Studio's extensibility features with PowerShell simple data visualizations exposed by StudioShell leveraging existing PowerShell tools inside of Visual Studio event-driven scripting

m:properties.d:title: What's New in Silverlight 5
m:properties.d:description: Silverlight 4 has been available for over a year now and developers have been chomping at the bits for new features. And Silverlight 5 delivers" From 3D to Databinding, Networking, Text, Graphics, and Tooling enhancements to performance improvements, Silverlight 5 is going to be a huge improvement. In this session, Matt will review and demonstrate all of the new features in the Silverlight 5 beta.

m:properties.d:title: SilverLight PivotViewer: Data Made Awesome
m:properties.d:description: If you are not familiar with SilverLight's PivotViewer control, visit http://xboxindies.com/games/PivotDatabase.aspx for a real world example. Built by combining DeepZoom with structured meta data, PivotViewer creates a powerful and unique experience when working with large sets of data. This session will cover the fundamentals behind creating your own Pivot database and PivotViewer application. Advice from experience will be shared on maintaining a Pivot database, from the small (1,000 items) to the large (60,000+). The session will also touch on several scenarios for using Pivot databases, and approaches to consider for each case.

m:properties.d:title: What Software Developers Can Learn From Forrest Gump
m:properties.d:description: Remember the movie Forrest Gump? Forrest had this incredible ability to tell a story that kept audiences glued to their seat yet he wasn't that smart. Turns out there are many things developers can learn from Forrest. Developers are notorious for complicating things. We have this natural ability to make the simplest of things sound overly complicated, not to mention we use acronyms for everything. In this session we are going to look at three areas developers can apply Forrest Gump techniques. They are: communication, presenting technical information and writing code. By the end of the session you'll be speaking, writing or presenting Gumpology with the best of them.

m:properties.d:title: Opening Keynote
m:properties.d:description: Topic TBA
